body_html:
Registering tf.identity() as the gradient of tf.placeholder_with_default() makes sense to me as a first step.

The only downside—as @gaohuazuo implied—is that if you feed a value for a tf.placeholder_with_default() and consume its gradient, the gradient will depend on the default value, which might run counter to expectations. I'm open to suggestions on what the right behavior should be here.

Registering tf.identity() as the gradient of tf.placeholder_with_default() makes sense to me as a first step.
The only downside—as @gaohuazuo implied—is that if you feed a value for a tf.placeholder_with_default() and consume its gradient, the gradient will depend on the default value, which might run counter to expectations. I'm open to suggestions on what the right behavior should be here.
body:
Registering `tf.identity()` as the gradient of `tf.placeholder_with_default()` makes sense to me as a first step.

The only downside—as @gaohuazuo implied—is that if you feed a value for a `tf.placeholder_with_default()` **and** consume its gradient, the gradient will depend on the default value, which might run counter to expectations. I'm open to suggestions on what the right behavior should be here.
